patterns: Information about Shree Narayana Guru College
responses: Shree Narayana Guru College, established in July 1986 by Sree Narayana Mandira Samiti, is located at P.L. Lokhande Marg, Chembur (West). It spans approximately 5 acres of greenery with two multi-storied buildings, near Chembur railway station and mono rail, and is well-connected by BEST buses. Initially aimed at serving the local student community, it now attracts students from across Mumbai, Navi Mumbai, and Thane. The college is permanently affiliated with the University of Mumbai, recognized by UGC under Sections 2(f) and 12B, and accredited thrice by NAAC. It is a Malayalam Linguistic Minority Institution known for its strict discipline, academic excellence, and promotion of sports and cultural activities. The college also focuses on enhancing students' soft skills and regularly organizes national-level seminars, conferences, and workshops, along with hosting 'Oasis', an inter-collegiate competition in sports and cultural events.

patterns: What are the programs offered by the college?
Programs at Shree Narayana Guru College
responses: Shree Narayana Guru College offers a variety of programs, including B.Com, B.Com (Management Studies), B.Sc. (Information Technology), B.Com (Banking & Insurance), B.A.M.M.C., B.Com (Accounting & Finance), B.Com (Financial Management), B.Com (Investment Management), B.Com (Transport Management), B.Com (Environment Management and Economics), B.Sc. (Data Science), and B.A. (Economics). For more details, please visit https://sngcollege.ac.in.
For detailed information on the fee structure, please contact us at 9326063380 or 9326083757, or email us at degree.sngcollege86@gmail.com.

patterns: Tell me about Shree Narayana Guru
responses: Shree Narayana Guru (20 August 1856 20 September 1928) was a renowned philosopher, spiritual leader, and social reformer in India. He led a reform movement against caste discrimination in Kerala, advocating for spiritual enlightenment and social equality. His famous quote 'one caste, one religion, and one god for all human beings' was a cornerstone of his movement. He also authored the Advaita poem Daiva Dasakam, widely used in Kerala for community prayers.
